questions.question: He …………………. be at home. I am not sure.
questions.description: We use may to express possibility.

questions.question: ……………………. I borrow your car?
questions.description: In an informal style, may is also possible here.

questions.question: I ……………………… climb that mountain when I was young.
questions.description: We use could to talk about past ability.

questions.question: It …………………….. be true.
questions.description: We do not use can in affirmative sentences to talk about possibility.

questions.question: She wondered whether it ………………………. be true.
You ……………………… not enter my house again. (Order)
questions.description: Shall can be used with second and third person pronouns to express a command, promise or threat.

questions.question: …………………….. I help you?
questions.description: Shall is used in polite offers of help.

questions.question: ……………………… I get you something to drink?
If it ………………………. rain, we will cancel the picnic.
questions.description: Should is often used in conditional clauses to express a supposition that may not be true.

questions.question: I ……………………….. have my way in this matter.
He ……………………….. not wait for me.
questions.description: When need is a modal auxiliary, it does not take –s in the third person singular.
